text: hi guys I'm Laura Vitale and on this
episode of Laura in the kitchen I'm
going to show you how to make an oldie
but goodie we're gonna make a peach
cobbler now there are so many variations
of it of course and this is my take on
it and I hope that you enjoy it let me
take you over the ingredients so we can
get started you're going to some fresh
peaches all-purpose flour plain old
sugar egg whole milk baking powder salt
a squeeze of lemon some additional sugar
a pinch of cinnamon and some unsalted
butter
okay now traditionally peach cobbler is
made with canned peaches and like a
biscuit topping I don't like either one
I don't like canned peaches and I don't
like the biscuit topping on a peach
cobbler because I think it's about to
dry and I might as well just get a peach
crisp I might as well just get it all
the way and get it real crisp you know
what I mean so I make mine with just a
really fluffy batter now use fresh
peaches which I've sliced and I've taken
out the pit and I peeled them first
obviously but you don't have to peel
them if you don't want to and all I'm
going to do is I'm going to put them
into my saucepan because I adore fresh
peaches especially when they're in
season but I feel like they need to be
cooked down just a little tiny bit so
that they're nice and soft because if I
were to put them in the cobbler as is I
find that they're a little too hard by
the time the cobbler is done so I'm
adding in a little lemon juice a little
bit of sugar and some cinnamon and I'm
just going to cook this mixture for
about a minute or until it comes up to a
bubble and it's really all it takes and
then that's happening you want to make
sure you oven is preheated to 350 I've
done that already and then I've taken
some unsalted butter and I'm going to
put it in my 9 by 13 inch pan here and
I'm going to stick this into the ovens
of the butter can melt kill two birds
with one stone and then I mean you're
right back here to finish it up in this
big bowl I'm going to pretty much add in
the remaining ingredients and this is
how simple it is you got your flour
you've got your sugar you've got your
baking powder pinch of salt of course
I'm just going to mix this together just
for a second my peaches are up to a boil
I can turn those off and as those cool
down just a bit I'm going to finish
making my batter you add in your egg and
your milk so as you can tell this is a
very difficult recipe and I'm hoping you
can sense the sarcasm in that so all I'm
going to do is just get this nice and
combined that looks perfect now I've got
my pan here with my melted butter and
this is a thing to remember with this
recipe you're going to pretty much add
things in layers without mixing them so
I'm going to pour my cake batter here
right on top of my butter not mixing it
something happens as it bakes we're all
bakes perfectly together don't ask me
why I won't do science or any of that I
just cook but I know that it works and
then you just take your peaches and then
you kind of just strip it them all over
the top and you just mix those around
kind of evenly and that's it that is all
you need to do and wait till you see
when it bakes it all bakes perfectly now
I'm going to pop this back into the oven
at 350 between 40 to 45 minutes and I'll
show you what it looks like once it's
done my cobbler baked for about 40
minutes and I've let it cool for about
10 minutes and now it's ready to go and
of course you need to serve it with
vanilla ice cream
but for right now I just really want to
show you what this looks like and like I
said this is how I prefer a cobbler
instead of like the Bisquick topping but
hey you know you do things how you want
I preferred like the cakey texture much
more but we didn't use canned peaches
but look how gorgeous these peaches
become especially since we cooked them
up for like a minute beforehand it's
like incredible I think there's the best
cobbler ever but you try it you let me
know and if you want to get the recipe
do a debbie wwr gets really hot
laurainthekitchen.com and i'll see you
next time bye bye
you
